Title: Non-existence of a Surjective Function from a Set to Its Subsets (Cantor's theorem)
Content: Show that: Let A be a set and let $P(A)$ be the set of all subsets of $A$. Then there is no surjection $f: A→P(A)$. Here is what I thought: if $A=\{a,b\}$ then it has only two elements where $P(A)=\{∅,\{a\},\{b\},\{a,b\}\}$ has 4 elements. Therefore $f:A→P(A)$ cannot be surjective. But I have some problems: 1) How is it possible that any $f$ function to take $\{a\}$ from set $A$ to $\{a,b\}$? Maybe because I am thinking mainly about functions with real values like $f(x)=2x$, I find it a little bit strange that a function to take an element of a set to another set which has more elements. Is it possible? edit: Now I thought that if $f(x)$ is $\sqrt{x}$, then $f(4)=±2$ which means it took an element from a set to a set which has 2 elements. But still I find it kind of strange to denote $f(\{a\})=\{a,b,c,...\}$ 2) How can I construct a explicit proof for this question? Regards

Cantor's theorem states: Suppose that $A$ is a set and $f\colon A	o\mathcal P(A)$ is any function, then $f$ is not surjective. The proof is quite simple, and constructive! Proof. Suppose that $f\colon A	o\mathcal P(A)$ is a function, we define $D=\{a\in A\mid a
otin f(a)\}$ . This is a good definition, since $f(a)$ is a subset of $A$ , and $a$ is an element of $A$ , we can ask whether or not $a\in f(a)$ . So $D$ is the set of those elements of $A$ which do not have this property. Of course that $D\in\mathcal P(A)$ since it is clearly a subset of $A$ . We will show that $f(a)
eq D$ for all $a\in A$ . If $a\in D$ then, by definition of $D$ , $a
otin f(a)$ . So $f(a)
eq D$ , since the element $a$ belongs to D but not to $f(a)$ . If $a
otin D$ then, by definition of $D$ , $a\in f(a)$ . By the same argument, again $f(a)
eq D$ . Either way, $D
eq f(a)$ for all $a\in A$ . Therefore $f$ is not surjective. $\square$ Note that for different functions we have different $D$ 's. It is possible that $D=A$ (e.g. if $f(a)=\varnothing$ for all $a$ ), or it could be $\varnothing$ (e.g. if $f(a)=\{a\}$ for all $a$ ). However regardless to its value it will not be in the range of $f$ .
